question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, after October 29, 2025 and before November 21, 2025, US federal agencies in the Washington, DC area have a status of Open, according to the [US Office of Personnel Management](https://www.opm.gov/policy-data-oversight/snow-dismissal-procedures/current-status/).

The question may also resolve according to [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/faq/#definitions) in the event of material issues with the main resolution source.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**U.S. Senate convenes on 34th day of shutdown with no vote taken**
The U.S. Senate reconvened on November 3, 2025, for the 34th day of a federal government shutdown, with no vote taken on a funding bill despite 13 failed procedural votes on a House-passed continuing resolution (CR) that would fund the government through November 21. The House has not been in session since September 19, and the shutdown began on October 1. Senate Majority Leader John Thune expressed cautious optimism about reaching a deal this week, citing weekend discussions, but emphasized that progress must be evident by midweek to meet the goal of sending a bill back to the House before the Senate recesses for Veterans Day. Thune opposes invoking the 'nuclear option' to eliminate the filibuster, stating there is insufficient support among Republicans for such a move, despite pressure from former President Donald Trump. The White House insists on passing a 'clean' CR before negotiations on healthcare, while Democrats demand extension of Affordable Care Act subsidies. A bipartisan group of four House lawmakers proposed a two-year extension of subsidies with an income eligibility cap. Senate Republicans hold a 53-47 majority but lack the 60 votes needed to overcome a filibuster. Essential workers, including air traffic controllers, are operating without pay, leading to widespread flight delays—5,890 on Sunday alone—and safety concerns, with 98 FAA facilities reporting staffing triggers. Over 670,000 federal employees have been furloughed and about 730,000 are working without pay, with no guarantee of back pay upon resolution. The White House labels the shutdown a 'Democratic shutdown' on its website and social media.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 04, 2025 01:41 AM
Source:[Yahoo](https://www.yahoo.com/news/articles/u-senate-convenes-34th-day-222345699.html)

**The 2025 U.S government shutdown, by the numbers**
The 2025 U.S. government shutdown, now the second-longest in history at 34 days as of November 3, 2025, is ongoing due to repeated failures in Congress to pass a temporary funding bill. The shutdown began on October 1 after the Senate failed to advance a House-passed resolution to fund the government through November 21, despite 13 failed votes. Of the 100 Senate members, 52 Republicans supported the resolution, while 43 Democrats and independents opposed it, including one Republican, Senator Rand Paul, who opposes the bill due to concerns over national debt. Only three Democrats/independents—Sens. John Fetterman, Catherine Cortez Masto, and Angus King—voted in favor. Senate Majority Leader John Thune stated that five Democratic senators would need to switch their votes to advance the bill. The shutdown has resulted in 670,000 federal workers being furloughed and 730,000 essential workers continuing to work without pay. Over 4,000 federal employees were targeted for layoffs, though a court has blocked those actions. Approximately 42 million Americans will lose Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefits on November 1, with a $9.2 billion cost to fund benefits for November, though the Agriculture Department’s $5 billion contingency fund cannot be legally accessed. President Trump claims a $130 million donation from Timothy Mellon, a billionaire, is being used to pay military personnel, though it covers only about $100 per service member. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the shutdown has caused at least $7 billion in sustained economic losses, with GDP dropping 1 percentage point after four weeks and 2 points after eight weeks. The shutdown’s economic impact is partially reversible, but long-term damage persists.
Original language: en
Publish date: November 03, 2025 02:29 PM
Source:[Aol](https://www.aol.com/articles/2025-u-government-shutdown-numbers-192107375.html)

**As they miss paychecks, furloughed federal workers are taking out bank loans to help pay the bills**
As the U.S. government shutdown entered its 30th day on November 1, 2025, furloughed federal workers are increasingly turning to zero-interest loans to cover essential expenses. A San Antonio woman, whose husband works for the Department of Defense, shared with CBS News that her family took a $3,200 no-interest loan from USAA to avoid financial hardship, stating they 'would have been in trouble' without it. USAA has issued over $365 million in such loans to more than 119,000 federal employees since the shutdown began on October 1, 2025. The loans, available up to $6,000 and repayable within 90 days, are designed to replace one net paycheck and carry no fees or interest. USAA, serving 14 million military, veteran, and family members, offers these loans as part of its crisis response. Navy Federal Credit Union is also providing a 'Paycheck Assistance Program' with similar no-interest loans up to $6,000, repaid automatically once employees receive back pay. Federal workers who miss paychecks are entitled to back pay once agencies reopen. The financial strain is compounded by delayed insurance claims and mounting bills, according to the woman, who emphasized that 'Insurance took some time to process it all, and things are starting to come in at a really bad time.'
Original language: en
Publish date: November 01, 2025 01:08 PM
Source:[news9.com](https://www.news9.com/story/69064c761328bc922242a4df/as-they-miss-paychecks-furloughed-federal-workers-are-taking-out-bank-loans-to-help-pay-the-bills)

**This government shutdown is not like the others: Furloughed federal workers explain**
A federal government shutdown that began on October 1, 2025, has now lasted nearly three weeks, affecting at least 700,000 federal employees who have been furloughed and nearly as many who are working without pay. The shutdown, unlike previous ones, is being used by President Trump and his administration to pursue aggressive restructuring of the federal bureaucracy, including mass firings, the elimination of programs, and the use of unorthodox budgetary maneuvers—some of which have been blocked by a federal judge but may still proceed. Federal workers across agencies report a toxic work environment marked by fear, instability, and systemic breakdowns. Adam, a recreation specialist with the US Forest Service in Idaho, describes a decline in staffing due to the deferred resignation program and a loss of morale, with trail maintenance now halted. Ellen, an employee at the USDA Food and Nutrition Service, highlights the disruption to SNAP and other nutrition programs, with states left without federal guidance on compliance and funding, and notes that her coworkers are volunteering at food banks to help fill the gap. April, from the Administration for Children and Families, emphasizes the interconnectedness of federal programs, particularly Head Start, SNAP, and refugee resettlement, and shares that the shutdown has disproportionately impacted Black federal workers and communities of color, many of whom have already left the workforce in record numbers. All three workers describe a coordinated effort by the administration to make federal work unbearable, including the use of AI to generate wrongful RIF (reduction-in-force) notices, system failures, and the erosion of union power. Despite this, solidarity among federal workers has grown, with increased organizing through groups like the Federal Unionists Network. The shutdown is not seen as a temporary disruption but as part of a broader strategy to dismantle public services and replace them with privatized or underfunded alternatives, according to the workers. The article underscores that the impact extends far beyond federal employees, affecting millions of Americans who rely on federal programs for food, housing, healthcare, and recreation.
Original language: en
Publish date: October 22, 2025 04:59 PM
Source:[therealnews.com](https://therealnews.com/this-government-shutdown-is-not-like-the-others-furloughed-federal-workers-explain)

**One Month of U.S. Government Shutdown: How Many Deadlines Were Missed?**
As of October 31, 2025, the U.S. government shutdown has entered its 31st day, marking a prolonged period of federal inactivity. Since October 1, 2025, numerous federal agencies and offices have been closed or operating at reduced capacity, resulting in missed deadlines across critical sectors. Key missed deadlines include: the failure of the U.S. Senate to pass a temporary funding bill before federal funds were exhausted; the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics missing its October 3 deadline for the monthly employment report; the closure of the National Archives, museums, and cultural institutions on October 12, disrupting tourism in Washington, D.C.; the U.S. Department of Labor postponing the release of the September Consumer Price Index (CPI) report on October 15; the U.S. federal court system exhausting its funds by October 20, leading to the unpaid furlough of 33,000 employees—the first such event in nearly 30 years; the U.S. National Nuclear Security Administration, under the Department of Energy, placing most staff on mandatory leave for the first time in its history; the October 28 payroll deadline for approximately 13,000 air traffic controllers and 50,000 Transportation Security Administration (TSA) officers, causing widespread flight delays and cancellations; the U.S. Department of Agriculture halting the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) on November 1, affecting 42 million low-income individuals and people with disabilities; and the postponement of the release of the third-quarter GDP data on October 30, forcing policymakers and businesses to operate without essential economic data. According to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, federal contractors lost an estimated $12 billion in the first four weeks of the shutdown, with small businesses losing $30 billion weekly. The Congressional Budget Office warned of potential losses between $7 billion and $14 billion if the shutdown continued. The shutdown could extend beyond 35 days, surpassing the 2018–2019 shutdown, if no temporary funding bill is passed by November 5. Analysts note that both parties are using the shutdown to advance political agendas, with Democrats demanding negotiations on extending Affordable Care Act subsidies and Republicans insisting on a vote on the funding bill first. Harvard scholar Linda Bilmes stated the shutdown severely undermines public confidence in government functionality.
Original language: zh
Publish date: October 31, 2025 11:20 PM
Source:[news.cri.cn](https://news.cri.cn/20251101/227028d6-d8d6-20eb-efef-2f8b5c3b6533.html)

**Employees are receiving renewed furlough notices as shutdown enters second month, this time without back pay guarantees**
The U.S. government shutdown entered its second month on November 1, 2025, prompting federal agencies to issue renewed furlough notices to approximately 650,000 employees. These updated notices, required every 30 days, no longer include language guaranteeing back pay upon the shutdown's conclusion—marking a significant departure from initial communications. **Pay for Trump and Congress continues in shutdown, unless they ask it be held**
During the ongoing U.S. government shutdown beginning October 1, 2025, federal employees, including 2 million civilian workers and legislative staffers, have missed their first full paychecks, while members of Congress, the president, and federal judges continue to receive their regular salaries. Congress members are legally entitled to pay under the U.S. Constitution (Article I, Section 6, Clause 1) and the 27th Amendment, which prohibits changes to congressional compensation until after an election. Although Congress has voted multiple times to withhold salaries during shutdowns, no such bill has become law. Nonetheless, several lawmakers—including Colorado Senator Michael Bennet, Florida Representative Kat Cammack, New Jersey Senator Andy Kim, Oklahoma Representative Stephanie Bice, Oregon Representative Janelle Bynum, and South Dakota Senator John Thune—have requested their pay be withheld during the shutdown. The Senate Financial Clerk and House Chief Administrative Officer confirmed that checks can be held at a member’s request, though the checks are still issued and can be picked up later. The Congressional Budget Office and Congressional Research Service both affirm that congressional pay is mandatory and cannot be legally withheld without specific statutory authority. However, members may voluntarily donate their salaries to the Treasury. In contrast, federal workers, including non-exempt executive branch employees and legislative staff, receive no pay during the shutdown. Exempt workers, such as those in national security or emergency response, continue working. A 2019 law mandates retroactive pay for furloughed and essential employees once funding resumes, but President Donald Trump and administration officials have cast doubt on whether this will be enforced for executive branch workers. The House Committee on Administration confirms that legislative branch employees will receive back pay after the shutdown ends.

**Why the U.S. Government Announced Its Shutdown at Midnight and What It Means**
The United States government is heading toward a federal shutdown at midnight on September 30, 2025, marking the start of fiscal year 2026 without a budget agreement approved by Congress. The impasse stems from political deadlock between Republicans and Democrats: the Senate rejected a Republican-proposed temporary funding bill extending funds to November without additional concessions, as well as a Democratic alternative that included protections for healthcare subsidies under the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare). The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) has directed federal agencies to activate contingency plans, including temporary or permanent layoffs in non-essential programs, aligned with Trump’s agenda to reduce bureaucracy. This would be the first shutdown since 2019 and the 21st in the past 50 years, intensified by internal party divisions and demands to protect expiring healthcare subsidies. The U.S. federal budget process requires approval of 12 individual appropriation bills or a continuing resolution (CR) to maintain prior-year funding levels—neither has been passed for fiscal year 2026. Despite White House meetings between Trump, House Speaker Mike Johnson, and leaders like Hakeem Jeffries, negotiations failed. Republicans, controlling both chambers, demand a 'clean CR' without political strings, while Democrats insist on linking funding to healthcare protections and reversing previous Medicaid cuts under Trump’s administration. The context is post-election, with Trump seeking to shrink the federal government, inspired by initiatives like 'Project 2025,' and threatening mass layoffs during the shutdown to eliminate 'non-essential' jobs. The OMB issued memos explicitly blaming Democrats, sparking accusations of ethical violations for politicizing official communications. Historically, shutdowns result from similar disputes—such as the 2018–2019 shutdown over the border wall—but this one could last longer due to partisan intransigence. A shutdown suspends non-essential federal operations under the Antideficiency Act of 1884, affecting approximately 2 million federal employees, including civilian Defense Department staff, who will be placed on furlough (unpaid leave) or work without guaranteed pay, though they will receive retroactive pay after resolution. Essential services—national security, air traffic control, Social Security, and Medicare—continue, but key economic reports like the monthly jobs report will be canceled, disrupting Federal Reserve decision-making. National parks will close, impacting tourism; the FAA will furlough 11,000 workers, risking flight delays; immigration processing, food inspections, and scientific research will halt, with estimated losses in the billions. This shutdown could increase global perceptions of instability in U.S. Treasury bonds, potentially raising interest rates. USCIS will suspend non-urgent immigration processes, affecting visa and asylum applicants. Long-term implications may include damage to the global economy, delayed foreign aid, and weakened international cooperation on climate and trade. Experts warn of a 'data blackout' that hampers monetary policy, with the Fed operating 'in the dark' without labor or inflation indicators. The private sector—airlines and tourism—will suffer losses, and financial markets may become volatile, boosting safe-haven assets like gold and the dollar. Internationally, aid and cooperation could be delayed. However, past shutdowns typically end within days or weeks due to public and economic pressure, with both parties sharing blame. The White House and Congress claim 'zero impunity' in negotiations, but Trump’s threats of further layoffs suggest prolonged uncertainty. The event underscores deep bipartisan dysfunction in Washington, where budgeting is used as a political tool, and highlights the urgent need for budgetary reform to prevent future shutdowns that cost billions and erode public trust.

**Federal agencies' government shutdown service and staff reduction**
Federal agencies are preparing for a potential government shutdown on October 1, 2025, following guidance from the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). Employees are categorized into three groups: furloughed (required to stop work), required to work without pay (excepted employees), or funded separately and continuing with pay. Paychecks for the September 7–20 pay period will be issued on time, but those covering work on or after October 1 may be delayed until appropriations are restored. All scheduled paid leave and holidays are canceled for affected staff. Employees may perform up to four hours of 'orderly shutdown' tasks to secure files and equipment. Special workforce cases, such as those in the Deferred Resignation Program or pending reductions-in-force, will be placed in furlough status. The White House, including President Donald Trump, has warned of potential large-scale layoffs if a shutdown occurs, with the Office of Management and Budget directing agencies to prepare both furlough and reduction-in-force notices for programs losing funding and not aligned with presidential priorities. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) estimates that a shutdown could furlough about 750,000 employees daily at a cost of $400 million per day, with economic losses persisting even after reopening—such as the $3 billion in lost output from the 2018–2019 shutdown. Key services that will continue include national defense, military operations, emergency response, border security, air traffic control, medical care at VA facilities, and critical health functions at HHS. Agencies like the Department of Commerce, Education, Health and Human Services, Homeland Security, Justice, Labor, State, Transportation, Treasury, Veterans Affairs, Pentagon, NASA, and Social Security Administration have detailed contingency plans. Notably, the IRS remains fully funded, and the VA continues benefits processing and medical care. The Department of War (Pentagon) will maintain military operations despite delayed pay for civilians. The CBO warns that prolonged shutdowns reduce consumer spending, disrupt contractors, and delay investments. Congress and active-duty military continue receiving pay, but federal workers face unpaid work. The White House emphasizes that these preparations are not needed if Congress passes stopgap funding.

summary: The forecasts from experts across public administration, legislative affairs, political science, economics, and American studies show a roughly even split on whether the US government shutdown will end before November 21, 2025. Forecasters universally note the shutdown's unprecedented length—currently tied for the longest in US history—and the extreme partisan and procedural deadlock, with a Senate filibuster, a House out of session, and both sides entrenched over ACA subsidies and budgetary demands. Several experts (notably in appropriations, economics, and partisan polarization) put the probability somewhat above even odds (60–80%), arguing that mounting social, economic, and political costs—especially missed paychecks, SNAP/WIC benefit losses, and potential chaos during Thanksgiving travel—will likely force a resolution in the final days before the deadline, as has generally happened in shorter past shutdowns. Others (legislative procedure, intergovernmental relations, political science institutionalism, and rational choice) put the probability lower (35–45%), contending that the strategic incentives for leadership—especially the Trump administration’s use of the shutdown to pursue permanent government restructuring and layoffs—make this standoff less responsive to typical pressure points. The dichotomy in probabilities (ranging from 35% to 80%, with clustering around 40% and 60–68%) reflects a consensus that, while resolution as deadlines approach is probable by historical precedent, the structure of the current impasse (heightened polarization, administration’s willingness to endure pain, procedural obstacles) makes a record-breaking, ultra-long shutdown a very real possibility. All forecasters agree that upcoming pay periods, escalating public hardship, and the approach of Thanksgiving are focal points for a possible deal, but warn that risks of inaction remain unusually high compared to prior episodes.
